The North’s political and business leaders are to gather in Gateshead this week for the first ever Convention of the North.
They hope to ensure that the North of England will speak with one voice on crucial issues such as investment in the rail network, making a success of Brexit and taking power away from London so that decisions are made locally.
Nick Forbes, leader of Newcastle City Council , said: “This is the North coming together as one, to speak about the issues that affect us.” The Convention of the North will take place at the BALTIC Centre for Contemporary Art in Gateshead (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
It’s been many centuries since the North had its own governing body. The Council of the North was created in 1472 by King Edward IV, but was abolished in 1641.
The Convention of the North takes place at the BALTIC Centre for Contemporary Art in Gateshead on Thursday, and the official host is Newcastle City Council.
Coun Forbes will open the event at 10am off a speech about the importance of giving more decision-making powers to the North.
Businessman Nigel Wilson, Chief Executive of Legal & General Group, will deliver the event’s key-note speech. The financial services firm has been a major investor the North East, contributing to the £350m development of Newcastle Science Central on the 24-acre site once used as the Newcastle Brown Ale brewery. The Convention of the North will take place at the BALTIC Centre for Contemporary Art in Gateshead (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
Panel discussions are expected to include senior figures from politics and business including Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham.
Former John Cridland, a former CBI Director General who now chairs transport body Transport for the North, is also expected to take part.
And Lord Shipley, a former leader of Newcastle City Council and now a Liberal Democrat member of the House of Lords, will also speak. Read More
Other speakers include Bradford Council leader Susan Hinchcliffe, who also leads West Yorkshire Combined Authority.
Liverpool City Region Mayor Steve Rotherham is expected to attend.
And delegates will hold meetings to discuss Brexit, skills and transport - and to ask for more control over the North’s affairs.
Coun Forbes said: “To give just some examples, at the moment we can’t set our own rail fares. We don’t get to decide where the rail network is improved, or which road schemes go ahead. Read More Labour MP Frank Field resigns and warns: 'We are seen as a racist party'
“When people voted for Brexit, they voted for change. But change is very difficult for central government to deliver.
“It’s going to have to be delivered in our towns and cities. That means we have to take more decisions in our communities.”
The North’s leaders are expected to call on the Government to invest in a scheme known as Northern Powerhouse Rail, which could include new rail services to Newcastle.
The Convention will also provide an opportunity to repeat calls for the North to have a seat at Brexit discussions. Like us on Facebook
